title: How taking the fear out of taking risks can help entrepreneurs grow their businesses
text:
One of the biggest roadblocks to entrepreneurial success is fear — fear of taking risks, fear of failure and even fear of handling unexpected success. But risks can be managed, and fear can be tamed. That’s the theme of an upcoming event focused on entrepreneurs hosted by HSBC Bank Canada, which features outspoken “dragon” investor Lane Merrifield, one of the stars of CBC’s Dragons’ Den.

It’s difficult to imagine that Merrifield — once the youngest executive vice-president at Disney, and founder of Club Penguin, the world’s largest social network ever built exclusively for young users — started out as a child who was once paralyzed by fear.

“Deathly afraid” are the words he uses to describe his early life. He turned down opportunities to attend summer camps because he was afraid to be separated from family and afraid of the dark. Worried about sleeping alone in his room, he camped out on the floor of his siblings’ bedrooms until he was a teenager.

“I needed to run my own life,” says Merrifield, “instead of letting fear take the driver’s seat.”

“I had some real anxiety issues,” he said recently. “But I decided that I couldn’t live like that any longer. I needed to run my own life, instead of letting fear take the driver’s seat.”

As a teenager, he made his first concrete steps to address his fears head-on with a detailed step-by-step approach. At the time, Merrifield found it challenging to even walk into a video store and select some movies to rent.

“I concentrated on just taking the first step,” he recalled. “I used to count how many steps it would take to get into that video store and back out again. What’s it going to take for me to just get out of the car, and then once I’m out of the car now I’m just going to walk into that video store. Now once I’m in that video store, I’m going to look up but I’m going to find the children’s section and I’m going to hang out there for a little bit. It was always about that next step.”

Merrifield also took a big risk when he told Dave Krysko, his boss at New Horizons Interactive, that he and co-worker Lance Priebe were so passionate about developing the idea that became Club Penguin that they would have to resign if they couldn’t work on the project there.

But that risk paid off, when his boss agreed to develop the product in-house. Club Penguin became wildly popular among kids worldwide and spurred a US$350-million buyout by Disney in 2007. Merrifield continued on as executive vice-president of Disney Interactive until 2013, when he helped found Wheelhouse Ventures, a group that invests in tech companies and helps small start-ups to grow.

Taking the fear out of taking risk is a theme that also resonates with HSBC Bank Canada, which continues to find new ways to serve small business clients across the country. As these ventures face the risks and challenges of growing their businesses, HSBC Bank Canada has their backs – by providing financial solutions tailor-made for their needs and challenges, including a range of everyday banking solutions, credit and lending tools, payment solutions and business credit card offerings.

For example, with HSBC Small Business Banking, small business owners can manage and track transactions through mobile and online banking, receive support from a dedicated HSBC Business Relationship Manager and enjoy a tailored banking solution that fits their small business. They can apply for a small business line of credit and receive a decision quickly when they use HSBC eCredit™.

HSBC Bank Canada also helps small businesses to manage their cash flow by offering a range of payment choices that allow them to easily receive funds from customers and make payments to vendors. In addition, the HSBC BusinessVantage® Mastercard® also provides features designed to suit small business.

“I’m not fearless and I don’t love risk,” says Merrifield. “But today, I can easily talk to audiences about Club Penguin and the sale to Disney. I appear on television on Dragon’s Den, which is watched by viewers from coast to coast. But that all started with taking the first step to conquer my fears.”

The HSBC Bank Canada event is scheduled for Nov. 28 in Toronto. The event also offers a workshop by Canadian technology trend guru Amber Mac on how small businesses can benefit from tech disruption.

description: Lane Merrifield of Dragons’ Den will share his thoughts on fear and risk-taking at an HSBC Small Business Banking event in November.
